abstracts.cdata!:
The overall development objectives of
            the Sustainable Energy Development Project for Rwanda are
            to: a) alleviate power shortages; and 2) enhance the
            capabilities of the energy sector institutions. This
            environmental assessment (EA) document evaluated impacts, as
            follows : loss of vegetation; erosion. sedimentation, loss
            of fertile soils, wildlife and biodiversity; lack of urban
            storm water sewerage and solid waste disposal facilities;
            unregulated dumping of wastes; choice and location of power
            systems and infrastructure; Rwanda's administrative,
            legislative and regulatory framework policies on the
            environment, and applicability of the Bank's safeguards
            policies : OP 4.01 Environmental Assessment; OD 4.20
            Indigenous Peoples( may apply); OP 4.12 Involuntary
            Resettlement; inefficient enforcement of environmental
            regulations; hydrology; irrigation water requirements;
            handling, transportation and storage of fuel and lubricants;
            noise levels and air quality; technical assistance and
            institutional strengthening required for Electrogaz, the
            project implementing agency; training requirements;
            employment opportunities; social services and
            infrastructure. As a result of this assessment the EA
            suggest mitigations measures, including : an Environment
            Advisor will hired to monitor as stated in the cleared EMP,
            during construction and installation, the activities of the
            contractors to ensure that the works are being carried out
            as stated in the approved designs; review of technical and
            environmental specifications, before the generators are
            shipped to Rwanda; contract documents will include details
            of all mitigation measures; final design that does not
            comply with the requirements of the environmental laws of
            Rwanda and the requirements of the Bank safeguards policies
            will not be approved by Rwanda Environmental Management
            Authority (REMA); monitor air quality and alert communities
            when air quality is poor and could damage their health;
            ensure safe and reliable road transportation of fuel;
            provide site staff with suitable safe clothing, shoes and
            health protection equipment; minimize dust propagation by
            spraying water on roads adjacent to construction sites;
            trucks carrying soil, sand and gravel will be duly covered
            to avoid spilling; low emission construction equipment and
            vehicles will used; litter, fuels, oil drums, used
            cartridges will be collected and disposed properly;
            encourage contractors to hire local workers as much as
            possible; contractors must clean sites or areas contaminated
            from spillages and leakages; source backfill material and
            sand must be taken from approved locations; enforce regular
            inspections of all piping systems from storage to
            generators; select land for transmission  and distribution
            (T&D) network grids, and expansion of substations to
            house new generators, which will not impact Project Affected
            Peoples PAPs)'s economic resources; recommend changes
            in to system designs to protect ecosystems at risk; promote
            peaceful resolutions to land disputes; develop a plan for
            technical assistance and institutional strengthening for
            participating project implementing agencies; and finally,
            promote information campaigns with community members and
            project affected peoples (PAPs) on environment best
            practices throughout implementation of the project.
